body: Early feedback: awesome.
@mdeuser I think what @dubeejw proposed and I understood was to leave the semantics the same as today.

Hi ,

Running this harness on a OpenWhisk deployment running on a native Ubuntu system runs into failures.
The noopLatency action is created and can be invoked via "wsk cli" but in the latency test "docker run" is used. Can you explain what is happening? It seems loadtest is being run in a docker container (outside the wsk system, since its not invoked by wsk) and then invokes the noop action "n" number of times. Is that whats happening? - Anyway I hit this error:

```
docker run --rm markusthoemmes/loadtest loadtest -n 10000 -k -m POST -H Authorization: basic MjNiYzQ2YjEtNzFmNi00ZWQ1LThjNTQtODE2YWE0ZjhjNTAyOjEyM3pPM3haQ0xyTU42djJCS0sxZFhZRnBYbFBrY2NPRnFtMTJDZEFzTWdSVTRWck5aOWx5R1ZDR3VNREdJd1AK http://10.x.x.y:10001/api/v1/namespaces/_/actions/noopLatency?blocking=true
headers: object, {"host":"10.x.x.y:10001","user-agent":"loadtest/2.3.0","accept":"*/*","authorization":" basic MjNiYzQ2YjEtNzFmNi00ZWQ1LThjNTQtODE2YWE0ZjhjNTAyOjEyM3pPM3haQ0xyTU42djJCS0sxZFhZRnBYbFBrY2NPRnFtMTJDZEFzTWdSVTRWck5aOWx5R1ZDR3VNREdJd1AK"}
```

@hsane2001 you need to "disable" the system limits if you want to run this test harness. Configure them in your environment using the `limits` key.

You're getting 429, which means you're getting throttled.
@mdeuser, take another look. Made some updates to keep the current semantics in place.
PG1~1906 All up to date

This is interesting as `--web` is implemented as a set of annotations under-the-hood, but doesn't look like one to the user. It would be decidedly non-intuitive for `wsk update action test test.js --web true` to remove all other annotations as `--web true` doesn't _look_ like you're dealing annotations.

What I would expect to happen:

1 `wsk update action test test.js --web true` : all current annotations are not touched
2 `wsk update action test test.js --web true -a foo bar` : all other annotations other than foo are removed

From my point of view, `--web` doesn't look like `-a` and so should not touch anything added with `-a`. My understanding of the conversation above is that this is what @dubeejw has implemented in this PR.

That's my understanding Rob and my desire also. 
Can you confirm @dubeejw ?
I got same error with local environment. the solution that worked for me was to do setup.yml before couchdb.yml .
Great contribution, thank you :+1:. And: First contribution 🎉

Thx Jef ! I had followed same steps... Infact I had tried same steps on distributed env as well. Later on I figured out that even ping/pong curl related issue has nothing to do with final step up, as containers are up and running. Also moving ahead to next steps later on makes it working. Somehow I feel these issues are more in local env rather than distributed. For me it has something to do with ports.. 10001 and 12001.

Thanks for the pointers! I pushed another commit addressing the issues raised so far. Normally I'd squash/rebase and do a force push, but wasn't sure how the project preferred to handle that during code reviews and before merging.

Thanks for the contribution and for not squashing the revision! Indeed it helps with reviews not to constantly squash.

Usually the committers can rebase, squash and update the commit message as the PR is merged.
@akrabat, @csantanapr, current code in the PR to has the described functionality. Just needs a final review. Feel free to test it out.
@bbrowning congratulations to your first contribution and welcome to the OpenWhisk gang 🎉

@devbv 
I was running the wsk command from the openwhisk/bin directory and it was saying that wsk command not found. i came to know that i forgot to run the postdeployement.yml script so i ran it but it failed with the following error.

Probably not what this PR was wanting to remedy, but since this came up....

>wsk update action test test.js --web true -a foo bar : all other annotations other than foo are removed

That behavior may change in the future to "only the annotation foo is updated/created; all other annotations are left as-is"

see also https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/76
We know about this issue, will try to mitigate until Swift brings the binaries back.
I am not sure about api-gateway... but it can be a no_proxy issue.

@devbv does your pr apply here perhaps? https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2557

urls generated by the api gw when creating an api are available via `wsk api list FILTERS` or `wsk api list FILTERS --full`.  the former provides the api details in a single row; the latter breaks out the api details into multiple rows - with the url being on a separate line.

so, i believe the desired api url information is provided.  if this was the last sticking point and baring no other objections, i agree that this issue can be closed.

@zhy989 
I was facing the same error and the issue was with the couchdb setup. Did you do the couchDB setup before you ran the openwhisk.yml

Follow the steps given here https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/db/README.md

And then you can follow this section
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/README.md#deploying-using-couchdb

Note that as per the experts consul is no longer a part of openwhisk and I could see it in your logs. So it might be better to pull the code again and compile it.

@perryibm 
Perry very useful information. 
In our scenario it is not a burst of events but rather a continuous thing. Note that we are trying to handle the max scenario. So there could be 1M/second events happening through lot of devices which will then come to a openwhisk cluster, which will handle all of them. It is not clear at this point what different types of events would we have and how much processing for each type is required. there could be event that needs to be just transferred to kafka and further to internal database. Others might have some processing to do.

So do you thing depending upon the system power and memory it is possible to setup an openwhisk cluster that can handle 1M/sec events? I am not sure how we can setup this cluster up but we are trying to gauge if openwhisk can support our scenario.

thanks again for your time and help.
regards
@mdeuser, anything else on this one?
@fernandodelaiglesia -> I hit the same issue where Consul would hang on coming up in the native environment, I resolved it when I unset PROXY variables in my environment.

@spattewar 

consul did
1) store environment variables
2) check health of invokers

but now it is removed and a controller maintains membership of invoker itself.

Openwhisk use https for secure connection and you just failed with that.
Check nginx logs by command 'docker logs nginx -f'

@devbv

There are no logs under the nginx folder under wsklogs. Will the above command check the same logs file?

Thank you
Regards
check that your /tmp/nginx directory is not owned by root - if it is delete it and redeploy nginx.
In principle we can accept this change - it's partly addressed by #2524

It seems has some problem for the `travis-ci`, https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-openwhisk/builds/262507767?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification

But it seems has no relation with this pr.

You can see variable `defaultLimits`  is defined in `ansible/groups_vars/all` only,
the `- name: (re)start controller` ansible task has a ENV `"DEFAULTLIMITS_ACTIONS_INVOKES_PERMINUTE": "{{ defaultLimits.actions.invokes.perMinute }}"`. so after modified for `limits`, `limits` and `defaultLimits` are symmetrical
Nobody go on progress this PR?

@ningyougang it is key though, that you are able to override limits in an environment, which is why the `defaultLimits` are global and `limits` are "local". I agree the existing scheme isn't perfect, in fact it is quite wrong with the recent changes now.

What we should do:
1. Remove `defaultLimits`, have only `limits`
2. Make each key in `limits` overridable, such as

```
limits:
  invocationsPerMinute: "{{ limit_invocations_per_minute | default(120) }}"
  concurrentInvocations: "{{ limit_invocations_concurrent | default(100) }}"
  concurrentInvocationsSystem:  "{{ limit_invocations_concurrent_system | default(5000) }}"
  firesPerMinute: "{{ limit_fires_per_minute | default(60) }}"
  sequenceLength: "{{ limit_sequence_length | default(50) }}"
```

That is: It adjusts the wording to conform with the `UserLimits` class. It also allows selective overriding per environment (by defining one of the `limit_...` variables), but keeps defaults up top.

What do you think?

Having the option to control the entrypoint name allows me to have multiple entrypoints in the same class. For instance a create and an update action on the same model are very similar, why should I be **forced** to separate them over 2 classes.

I did a small test to see the impact of a separate class on jar size:

- Add same entrypoint to different class increased jar file by 700 bytes
- Duplicating the entrypoint in the same class (with different name) increases jar file by 27 bytes

This was done with a plain hello world action.

I know that if I was really concerned about jar size I should include only a single action in the jar file and remove everything not used by that single action. But from a coding perspective (sourcecode readability) this separation seems like additional complexity to me, making it harder to understand. I like to see it more like a REST resource, where I would put the various operations on that resource close together as well.
